Sean Oliver

17 March 2014

Pick a Small Market

I recently attended a talk by Peter Thiel at LiveRamp's RampUp Conference. One of the things he said really resonated with me:

Peter Thiel: "When you start a company, you want to get big market share as quickly as possible, so pick a small market." #startups

— Sean Oliver (@seanoliver) February 28, 2014

You may be thinking "well, duh." What sense does it make to go after a big, expensive, diffuclt market when you have no resources?

In practice, it's hard to pick a small market. Mostly because it's hard to find a market small enough for you to get traction quickly, but large enough to sustain your business.

This runs contrary to the popular notion that having competitors "validates" your market. And while that might be true, a validated market doesn't do you much good if you're losing market share to competitors.

The truth is, it's hard to find a problem today that some company isn't working on solving. Even then, the proliferation of startups has made it such that finding an unsolved problem will surely bring about copycats, looking to outdo you at your own game and capitalize.

That's why it's not really about finding a small market. It's about finding a competitive advantage. It's about finding a defensible market position, and making it very difficult for others to encroach on your territory as quickly as possible. It isn't easy for small companies to do this, that's why Peter Thiel recommends finding a small market, something unsexy that few other people would be interested in getting involved in, and then expanding into other, sexier markets.
